articles.headline: The Quiet Force Behind DreamWorks
articles.snippet: Bill Damaschke, the chief creative officer of the film studio, is increasingly calling the artistic shots as the head of DreamWorks, Jeffrey Katzenberg, focuses on other areas.
articles.abstract: Bill Damaschke, the chief creative officer of the film studio, is increasingly calling the artistic shots as the head of DreamWorks, Jeffrey Katzenberg, focuses on other areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Calif. — Inside a modest upstairs office at DreamWorks Animation here — the one next to a framed poster reading “You’ve Got the Goods, Step Out and Show ’Em!” — sits one of the film industry’s most important executives. His name is Bill Damaschke.

articles.headline: Egyptian Liberals Embrace the Military, Brooking No Dissent
articles.snippet: Liberal Egyptians have long had an uneasy relationship with the military, but since the military pushed out President Mohamed Morsi, a majority of liberals have been intolerant of dissenters.
articles.abstract: Liberal Egyptians have long had an uneasy relationship with the military, but since the military pushed out President Mohamed Morsi, a majority of liberals have been intolerant of dissenters.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — In the square where liberals and Islamists once chanted together for democracy, demonstrators now carry posters hailing as a national hero the general who ousted the country’s first elected president, Mohamed Morsi, of the Muslim Brotherhood. Liberal talk-show hosts denounce the Brotherhood as a foreign menace and its members as “sadistic, extremely violent creatures” unfit for political life. A leading human rights advocate blames the Brotherhood’s “filthy” leaders for the deaths of more than 50 of their own supporters in a mass shooting by soldiers and the police.

articles.headline: 787 Fire Inquiry Focuses on Transmitter
articles.snippet: The emergency transmitter, which would send out the plane’s location in the event of a crash, is powered by a small lithium-manganese battery.
articles.abstract: The emergency transmitter, which would send out the plane’s location in the event of a crash, is powered by a small lithium-manganese battery.
articles.lead_paragraph: British safety investigators are examining whether a malfunction in an emergency locator transmitter or other equipment in the rear of a Boeing 787 Dreamliner caused the plane to catch fire on Friday at Heathrow Airport in London, federal and industry officials said Monday.

articles.headline: Legal Immigrants Seek Reward for Years of Following the Rules
articles.snippet: As the debate over immigration reform continues, more than 4.4 million legal immigrants languish in a broken visa system.
articles.abstract: As the debate over immigration reform continues, more than 4.4 million legal immigrants languish in a broken visa system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Angeles P. Barberena has always tried to follow the United States’ immigration laws. She dutifully filed her petition to become a resident, complied with the requirements and paid her taxes and fees.

articles.headline: Last Car Plant Brings Detroit Hope and Cash
articles.snippet: A sprawling factory that churns out the profitable Jeep Grand Cherokee has become a symbol of hope that Detroit’s downward spiral can be reversed.
articles.abstract: A sprawling factory that churns out the profitable Jeep Grand Cherokee has become a symbol of hope that Detroit’s downward spiral can be reversed.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — There is a section of Detroit’s east side that sums up the city’s decline, a grim landscape of boarded-up stores, abandoned homes and empty lots that stretch all the way to the river.

articles.headline: On Wall Street, a Culture of Greed Won’t Let Go
articles.snippet: A report on ethical conduct surveyed 250 industry insiders, a quarter of whom said they would engage in insider trading to make $10 million if there were no repercussions.
articles.abstract: A report on ethical conduct surveyed 250 industry insiders, a quarter of whom said they would engage in insider trading to make $10 million if there were no repercussions.

articles.headline: Arsenal of Legal Firepower Masses Around Tourre Trial
articles.snippet: Sean Coffey and Pamela Chepiga are representing Fabrice Tourre, Matthew Martens is leading the S.E.C.’s case against Mr. Tourre, and Judge Katherine Forrest will preside.
articles.abstract: Sean Coffey and Pamela Chepiga are representing Fabrice Tourre, Matthew Martens is leading the S.E.C.’s case against Mr. Tourre, and Judge Katherine Forrest will preside.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Wall Street lawyers gathered at a conference in Orlando, Fla., during the 2008 financial crisis, one law firm posted an outsize picture of Sean Coffey’s head on the body of a wrestler, labeling him Public Enemy No. 1.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Susanne Craig and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: 2 New Plans to Upgrade Smartphones After a Year
articles.snippet: AT&T plans to announce on Tuesday a way for customers to upgrade phones sooner. T-Mobile unveiled a similar option last week.
articles.abstract: AT&T plans to announce on Tuesday a way for customers to upgrade phones sooner. T-Mobile unveiled a similar option last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: For devotees of new technology, the people who help set trends and chase the latest gadgets, the joy of buying a new smartphone has been met with an equally strong annoyance: long-term commitment.

articles.headline: Panama Seizes Korean Ship, and Sugar-Coated Arms Parts
articles.snippet: A freighter on its way from Cuba to North Korea was found carrying missile-system components cloaked in a cargo of sugar, the Panamanian authorities said.
articles.abstract: A freighter on its way from Cuba to North Korea was found carrying missile-system components cloaked in a cargo of sugar, the Panamanian authorities said.
articles.lead_paragraph: It started with a tip: that a rusty North Korean freighter, which had not plied the Caribbean in years, was carrying drugs or arms amid more than 200,000 sacks of Cuban brown sugar.
articles.byline: By Rick Gladstone and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Senators Reach Agreement to Avert Fight Over Filibuster
articles.snippet: Lawmakers on Tuesday reached a deal to preserve the delaying tactic in exchange for Senate confirmation of President Obama’s long-sought nominee for consumer protection chief.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers on Tuesday reached a deal to preserve the delaying tactic in exchange for Senate confirmation of President Obama’s long-sought nominee for consumer protection chief.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders reached an agreement on Tuesday to preserve the filibuster in exchange for confirmation votes on President Obama’s stalled nominees, ending, at least for now, months of partisan warfare that threatened the stability of several federal agencies and a generation of procedural traditions.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Jennifer Steinhauer
